# Corporate governance

As Hong Kong’s central banking institution, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) understands the importance of good governance in maintaining and safeguarding public trust and confidence in its performance of statutory duties. It is therefore committed to upholding high standards of corporate governance.

To fulfil its commitment to good corporate governance, the HKMA:

- has established a clear corporate governance framework;
- maintains high accountability and transparency, and keeps in close contact with stakeholders; and
- implements robust and sound monitoring measures to manage risks and ensure that the conduct of employees at all levels and their day-to-day operations comply with specified standards.

The HKMA’s governance structure comprises several key elements, including statutory advisory committees that provide advice and guidance, accountability and transparency, and internal monitoring and external audit.

# The HKMA and the HKSAR Government

The HKMA is part of the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China (HKSAR Government), but may employ staff on terms different from those of civil servants in order to attract people with appropriate experience and expertise. The Chief Executive of the HKMA and its staff are public officers. The HKMA’s day-to-day operations are highly autonomous within the statutory powers conferred on or delegated to the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining Hong Kong’s monetary policy objectives and monetary system. In a letter dated 25 June 2003 to the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Financial Secretary stipulated that monetary stability should be maintained through a Currency Board System, keeping the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate at around 7.80 to 1 US dollar. The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible for achieving the monetary policy objectives on his own, including determining the relevant strategy, tools and implementation methods, and for maintaining the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s monetary system.

With the assistance of the Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury, the Financial Secretary is responsible for policies to maintain the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s financial system and to preserve Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre. To implement these policies, the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has the following responsibilities:

- promoting the overall stability and effective operation of the banking system;
- working with other relevant institutions and organisations to develop the debt market;
- handling matters relating to the issuance and circulation of legal tender banknotes and coins;
- promoting the safety and efficiency of financial infrastructure by developing payment, clearing and settlement systems, and, where appropriate, being responsible for operating such systems; and
- working with other relevant institutions and organisations to promote confidence in Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, and implementing appropriate market development measures to help strengthen the international competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial services.

The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund under the powers delegated by the Financial Secretary.

# Advisory committees and management

# Advisory committees

Advisory committees provide advice and guidance on the HKMA’s main areas of work.

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee was established under the Exchange Fund Ordinance to advise the Financial Secretary on matters relating to the exercise of his control over the Exchange Fund. The Financial Secretary is the ex-officio Chairman of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and other members (including the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority) are appointed by the Financial Secretary in a personal capacity under the authority of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. Members are appointed on the basis of their professional knowledge and experience, which greatly benefits the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee. The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has five sub-committees responsible for monitoring the HKMA’s work in specific areas and providing advice, and for reporting and making recommendations to the Financial Secretary through the Advisory Committee. Details of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee and its five sub-committees are set out on pages 53 to 63.

The Banking Advisory Committee and the Deposit-taking Companies Advisory Committee advise the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region on matters relating to the Banking Ordinance, particularly in relation to the conduct of banking business or deposit-taking business (as the case may be) by banks, deposit-taking companies and restricted licence banks. Both committees are chaired by the Financial Secretary, and their members include the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and persons appointed by the Financial Secretary under the authority of the Chief Executive. Details of the Banking Advisory Committee and the Deposit-taking Companies Advisory Committee are set out on pages 64 to 65.

# Management

The Executive Committee consists of the Chief Executive of the HKMA, the Deputy Chief Executive and other senior officers, and is chaired by the Chief Executive of the HKMA. The Executive Committee meets regularly to report to the Chief Executive on the progress of major work in the HKMA’s departments and to advise him on policy matters relating to the HKMA’s operations. The list of members of the Executive Committee is set out on pages 66 to 67.

# Accountability and transparency

The HKMA has maintained a high degree of autonomy in its day-to-day operations and in the methods used to implement government policy objectives, while being supported by high levels of accountability and transparency.

The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is appointed by the Financial Secretary, and the HKMA is therefore accountable to the public through the Financial Secretary. As the HKMA’s powers are established by laws passed by the Legislative Council, the HKMA is also accountable to the public through the Legislative Council. The HKMA also understands that it has a broader responsibility to promote public understanding of its role and objectives, and to keep a close eye on issues of concern to the community. In carrying out its day-to-day work and maintaining extensive contact with the community, the HKMA adheres to a policy of striving to enhance transparency and maintain openness. This policy has two main objectives:

- to enable the financial sector and the public to understand the HKMA’s work as fully as possible, subject to market sensitivities, commercial confidentiality and statutory restrictions on the disclosure of confidential information; and
- to ensure that the HKMA keeps in touch with public sentiment and responds appropriately to public opinion.

# Communication with the public

The HKMA is committed to promoting the stability of the monetary and banking systems, effectively managing official reserves, and developing and monitoring robust and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre and promoting its economic development.

For the HKMA to perform its duties effectively, it must gain the trust of the community. The HKMA therefore takes seriously its responsibility to explain its policies and work to the public in a rigorous manner. The HKMA maintains extensive contact with the media and uses social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the digital age. The HKMA also strives to address issues of public concern that fall within its remit, particularly by using traditional and social media to clarify misinformation and rumours about its policies in a timely manner.

In addition, the HKMA’s office has an information centre, consisting of a library and an exhibition hall, which is open to the public for six days a week for visits and use. Details of the HKMA’s work in communicating and engaging with the public are set out in the chapter on “Corporate Functions” (pages 185 to 191).

# The Legislative Council

The relationship between the HKMA and the Legislative Council is very important for enhancing accountability and transparency. The Chief Executive of the HKMA has undertaken to brief the Legislative Council’s Panel on Financial Affairs on the HKMA’s work and policies three times a year and to answer relevant questions. The briefings given by the Chief Executive of the HKMA to the Panel on Financial Affairs on a regular basis are available on the HKMA’s website.

In addition, representatives of the HKMA attend meetings of the Legislative Council’s panels and subcommittees from time to time to explain and discuss specific issues and to assist members in reviewing draft legislation.

# Information disclosure

The HKMA strives to achieve the highest international standards of transparency by publishing various journals and special publications in Chinese and English. The HKMA’s bilingual website (www.hkma.gov.hk) contains dedicated sections on economic research, statistical data, regulatory resources, consumer information and other topics, as well as a large number of publications, press releases, speeches and briefing papers published by the HKMA.

The HKMA reviews from time to time whether the disclosure of information on the accounts of the Exchange Fund and the Currency Board is adequate. The HKMA began participating in the IMF’s central bank “Special Data Dissemination Standard” programme in 1999. The HKMA also publishes the meeting minutes of the Issue Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, as well as reports on the operation of the Currency Board System. Since 1996, the HKMA’s website has contained banking regulatory policies and guidelines.

# Internal monitoring and external audit

The HKMA adopts robust and effective monitoring mechanisms to ensure high standards of staff conduct, prudent risk management, and appropriate checks and balances. The internal and external audit functions provide an independent assessment of whether the monitoring mechanisms are adequate and effective.

# Code of conduct

The Code of Conduct provides guidance on the ethical and legal responsibilities of employees, ensuring that the conduct of employees at all levels complies with specified standards.

# Internal monitoring

# Operational monitoring

As the first line of defence in risk management, all departments and divisions are responsible for identifying and assessing risks in their work processes and for establishing appropriate monitoring measures to ensure the smooth day-to-day operation of the HKMA.

# Enterprise risk management

Risk management is also carried out at the corporate level. The Risk Committee, chaired by the Chief Executive of the HKMA, is one of the cornerstones of the enterprise risk management framework.

The Risk Committee reviews and reports on potential and emerging risks identified by departments, and on whether the relevant monitoring measures and mitigation strategies are adequate, and determines appropriate follow-up actions.

# Internal audit

The HKMA’s Internal Audit Department independently assesses whether the governance processes, risk management and monitoring measures of different departments are adequate and effective, and makes recommendations for improvement.

# External audit

Under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the financial statements of the Exchange Fund are audited by the Audit Commission of the HKSAR Government. The Audit Commission does not charge a fee for this service. The audited financial statements of the Exchange Fund are published in the HKMA’s Annual Report.

# 經濟及金融環境

香港經濟在2024年錄得溫和增長，主要受惠於貨物出口在外部需求改善及全球科技周期復甦下有所反彈。勞工市場保持穩健，通脹在外圍價格壓力進一步減退下維持溫和。本港股市顯著回升，而物業市場則因市場氣氛在持續高息環境下受壓而大致疲弱。鑑於貿易緊張局勢不斷升級，預計2025年香港經濟將會面對充滿挑戰的外圍環境。然而，中國內地積極推出經濟刺激措施，加上為本地企業提供的多方面支持，應能鞏固營商信心。香港亦會繼續加強國際交往合作，以及深化區域合作。

# 經濟回顧

# 實體經濟活動

香港經濟在2024年溫和增長。實質本地生產總值繼2023年錄得3.2%的增幅後，在2024年按年上升2.5%（表1及圖1）。外圍方面，貨物出口在外部需求改善及全球科技周期復甦的帶動下恢復正增長，成為整體經濟增長的主要動力。服務輸出亦隨着訪港旅遊業的持續復甦，以及跨境金融及集資活動於下半年顯著增加而進一步增長。然而，由於服務輸入在出境旅遊業持續增長下顯著上升，抵銷了服務輸出對整體經濟增長所帶來的正面效應。本地方面，私人消費開支在本地居民的消費模式轉變下有所回軟。相反，物業成交增加以及營商氣氛在貨幣狀況逐步放寬下有所改善，帶動整體投資支出錄得輕微增長。

# 通脹及勞工市場

儘管新簽訂私人住宅租金逐步上升，本地成本壓力仍大致受控，加上外圍價格壓力逐步減退，本地通脹在2024年維持溫和（圖2）。2024年全年合計，基本及整體通脹率分別為1.1%及1.7%。

勞工市場在2024年表現穩健，失業率全年在2.9%至3.1%的低位徘徊（圖3）。自第1季起，總就業人數（圖3）逐步上升，勞動人口亦見增加，反映勞工需求與供應大致保持穩定。與此同時，隨着經濟持續增長，名義工資與勞工收入均錄得穩健增長。此外，政府在2024年《施政報告》中宣布進一步優化香港的吸引人才計劃，以紓緩不同行業的人手短缺問題，並透過吸納更多年輕人，為本地人口注入新動力。

# 股市

本港股市隨着9月中以來的大幅反彈，於2024年顯著轉向。具體而言，隨着美國聯邦儲備局（美聯儲）減息及內地推出積極的經濟刺激措施，市場氣氛顯著改善，帶動恒生指數在10月7日升至全年高位，收報23,100點（圖4）。然而，11月初舉行的美國總統選舉觸發市場對全球經濟前景及美聯儲放寬貨幣政策步伐的憂慮，本港股市略為回調。儘管如此，恒生指數於年底收報20,060點，較2023年年底大幅上升17.7%，終結連續四年下挫的走勢。

# 物業市場

住宅物業市場在2024年首三季大致疲軟，但在第4季出現回穩跡象。在2月底及10月中相關政策措施放寬，以及9月開始的減息周期的支持下，全年住宅成交量由2023年43,002宗的歷史低位大幅上升23.5%至2024年的53,099宗。然而，持續高企的按揭利率及一手市場累積的庫存，繼續對樓價構成下調壓力。因此，樓價在2024年按年下跌7.1%，置業負擔能力亦因而稍為改善，雖然仍屬偏緊。非住宅物業市場仍然疲弱。其中，寫字樓的空置率在供應充裕的情況下仍然高企，零售商舖則面對旅客與本地居民消費模式轉變所帶來的挑戰。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

鑑於貿易緊張局勢不斷升溫，並很可能會對國際貿易與資金流造成干擾，預計香港經濟於2025年將會面對充滿挑戰的外圍環境。然而，各有關當局及銀行業持續提供多方面的支持，應能提升本地企業的抗禦能力。內地積極推出經濟刺激措施，並且在前沿科技領域取得重大突破，亦應能提振營商信心。與此同時，香港會進一步深化區域合作，並加快聯動新興市場。同時，在內地當局的惠港旅遊政策，以及政府致力提振香港旅遊業的支持下，預計訪港旅遊業將會進一步增長。

# 通脹及勞工市場

預期本地通脹於2025年將保持溫和。由於房屋租金上升將逐步傳遞至消費物價，本地成本可能面對輕微的上升壓力。然而，儘管環球經濟前景的不確定性有所增加，但外圍價格壓力應會保持溫和。另一方面，勞工市場或會因貿易緊張局勢升溫而面對挑戰。然而，各項吸引人才計劃應有助繼續建立優質人才庫，為經濟長遠發展提供支持。

# 銀行體系表現

香港銀行體系在2024年維持穩健，銀行的資本及流動性均十分充裕。在宏觀經濟環境充滿挑戰下，年內銀行體系面對的信用風險增加，但銀行的整體資產質素維持可控。受惠於來自持有作交易的投資收益與收費及佣金收入上升，零售銀行盈利較2023年有所增長。

# 資產質素

銀行體系的特定分類貸款比率由2023年底的1.57%上升至2024年底的1.96%，逾期及經重組貸款比率於同期由1.24%升至1.55%（圖5）。特定分類貸款比率上升，主要是部分內地房地產發展商以及本地中小型發展商和投資者的貸款評級被下調所導致。然而，中國內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率由2023年底的2.58%，下降至2024年底的2.38%。銀行撥備維持充足。截至2024年底，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率（即信貸撥備和特定分類貸款比率）約為65%。若將抵押品變現價值從呆壞帳餘額中扣除，經調整的銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率約145%。與此同時，2024年底住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率仍然處於低水平，分別為0.11%及0.35%（圖6）。

資料來源：金管局

圖 6 住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率
資料來源：金管局

# 盈利走勢

零售銀行在2024年的整體除稅前經營溢利增加8.4%，同期除稅後平均資產回報率則由0.88%上升至0.93%（圖7）。盈利增長主要是由於持有作交易的投資收益（+97.0%）與收費及佣金收入增加（+15.4%），但部分升幅被淨利息收入減少（–5.2%）所抵銷。零售銀行淨息差由2023年的1.67%收窄至 2024 年的 1.52%（圖8）。與此同時，零售銀行成本與收入比率由2023年的38.9%微升至2024年的39.2%（圖9）。

資料來源：金管局

# 資產負債表走勢

銀行體系資產負債表在2024年擴大4.3%，主要是因為可轉讓債務工具增加（+13.4%）。由於借貸成本高企，貸款需求受壓，2024年貸款總額減少2.8%。其中在香港使用的貸款與在香港境外使用的貸款分別減少2.1%及5.7%，貿易融資則增加4.6%。中國內地相關貸款於2024年減少8.7%。

在資產負債表的負債方面，存款總額於2024年增加7.1%，相比2023年的增幅為5.1%。由於貸款總額減少而存款總額增加，整體貸存比率由2023底的62.8%降至2024年底的57.0%（圖10）。

# 資本充足水平

銀行體系在2024年資本維持充裕。2024年底本地註冊認可機構的綜合總資本比率為21.8%，相比上一年為21.1%；一級資本比率為19.9%（圖11）。兩者均遠高於相關國際最低要求。《巴塞爾協定三》槓桿比率於2024 年底為 8.0%（圖12）。

# 流動性狀況

銀行體系的流動性狀況維持穩健。第1類機構的季度平均流動性覆蓋比率在2024年第4季為178.4%，第2類機構的季度平均流動性維持比率為67.0%（圖13）。銀行體系的主要資金來源仍然是客戶存款。於2024年底，第1類機構的穩定資金淨額比率及第2A類機構的核心資金比率分別為143.4%及186.7%（圖14）。以上所有四個比率均遠高於法定最低要求。

# Economic and Financial Environment

Hong Kong’s economy recorded moderate growth in 2024, primarily driven by a rebound in goods exports as external demand improved and the global technology cycle recovered. The labour market remained robust, and inflation stayed moderate as external price pressures continued to ease. Hong Kong’s stock market saw a significant recovery, while the property market remained generally weak due to subdued market sentiment amid persistently high interest rates. Given the escalating trade tensions, Hong Kong’s economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, mainland China’s proactive economic stimulus measures, coupled with multifaceted support for local businesses, should help bolster business confidence. Hong Kong will also continue to strengthen international cooperation and deepen regional collaboration.

# Economic Review

# Real Economic Activity

Hong Kong’s economy grew moderately in 2024. Real local GDP rose by 2.5% year-on-year in 2024, following a 3.2% increase in 2023 (Table 1 and Chart 1). Externally, goods exports resumed positive growth, driven by improved external demand and a recovery in the global technology cycle, becoming the main driver of overall economic growth. Exports of services also grew further, supported by the continued recovery of inbound tourism and a significant increase in cross-border financial and fundraising activities in the second half of the year. However, the positive effect of service exports on overall economic growth was offset by a significant increase in service imports due to sustained growth in outbound tourism. Locally, private consumption expenditure softened as local residents’ consumption patterns changed. In contrast, overall investment expenditure recorded a slight increase, driven by a rise in property transactions and an improvement in business sentiment as monetary conditions gradually eased.

Source: Census and Statistics Department

Note: The quarterly change in seasonally adjusted local gross fixed capital formation is not available.
Source: Census and Statistics Department

# Inflation and Labour Market

Despite a gradual increase in newly signed private residential rents, local cost pressures remained largely under control, and external price pressures continued to ease, keeping local inflation moderate in 2024 (Chart 2). For the whole of 2024, the underlying and overall inflation rates were 1.1% and 1.7%, respectively.

The labour market performed well in 2024, with the unemployment rate hovering at a low level of between 2.9% and 3.1% throughout the year (Chart 3). Since the first quarter, total employment (Chart 3) has gradually increased, and the labour force has also grown, reflecting that labour demand and supply have remained largely stable. Meanwhile, as the economy continued to grow, nominal wages and labour income recorded solid growth. In addition, the government announced in the 2024 Policy Address further enhancements to Hong Kong’s talent admission schemes to alleviate manpower shortages in various industries and inject new impetus into the local population by attracting more young people.

Chart 2 Underlying consumer price inflation
Source: Census and Statistics Department

Chart 3 Labour market conditions
Source: Census and Statistics Department

# Stock Market

Hong Kong’s stock market saw a significant turnaround in 2024, with a substantial rebound from mid-September onwards. Specifically, as the US Federal Reserve cut interest rates and mainland China introduced proactive economic stimulus measures, market sentiment improved significantly, driving the Hang Seng Index to a year-high of 23,100 points on 7 October (Chart 4). However, the US presidential election in early November triggered market concerns about the global economic outlook and the pace of the Fed’s monetary policy easing, causing a slight pullback in Hong Kong’s stock market. Nevertheless, the Hang Seng Index closed at 20,060 points at the end of the year, up 17.7% from the end of 2023, ending a four-year losing streak.

# Property Market

The residential property market was generally weak in the first three quarters of 2024 but showed signs of stabilisation in the fourth quarter. Supported by the relaxation of relevant policy measures in late February and mid-October, and the start of an interest rate cut cycle in September, the number of residential transactions for the whole year increased significantly by 23.5% to 53,099 in 2024 from a historical low of 43,002 in 2023. However, persistently high mortgage rates and accumulated inventory in the primary market continued to put downward pressure on home prices. As a result, home prices fell by 7.1% year-on-year in 2024, and housing affordability improved slightly, although it remained tight. The non-residential property market remained weak. Office vacancy rates remained high amid ample supply, while retail shops faced challenges arising from changes in consumption patterns of visitors and local residents.

Source: Rating and Valuation Department and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited

# Economic Outlook

# Economic Environment

Given the escalating trade tensions, which are likely to disrupt international trade and capital flows, Hong Kong’s economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, the multifaceted support provided by relevant authorities and the banking sector should help enhance the resilience of local businesses. Mainland China’s proactive economic stimulus measures and its significant breakthroughs in frontier technologies should also help boost business confidence. Meanwhile, Hong Kong will further deepen regional cooperation and accelerate its engagement with emerging markets. In addition, inbound tourism is expected to grow further, supported by mainland authorities’ favourable tourism policies for Hong Kong and the government’s efforts to boost Hong Kong’s tourism industry.

# Inflation and Labour Market

Local inflation is expected to remain moderate in 2025. As rising housing rents gradually feed through to consumer prices, local costs may face slight upward pressure. However, despite increased uncertainty in the global economic outlook, external price pressures should remain moderate. On the other hand, the labour market may face challenges due to escalating trade tensions. However, various talent admission schemes should help continue to build a quality talent pool to support the economy’s long-term development.

# Banking Sector Performance

Hong Kong’s banking sector remained robust in 2024, with banks having ample capital and liquidity. Amid a challenging macroeconomic environment, credit risks faced by the banking sector increased during the year, but banks’ overall asset quality remained manageable. Retail banking profits grew compared with 2023, driven by higher investment income from holdings for trading and higher fee and commission income.

# Asset Quality

The banking sector’s classified loan ratio rose to 1.96% at the end of 2024 from 1.57% at the end of 2023, while the ratio of overdue and restructured loans increased to 1.55% from 1.24% over the same period (Chart 5). The increase in the classified loan ratio was mainly due to rating downgrades of loans to some mainland property developers and local small and medium-sized developers and investors. However, the classified loan ratio for mainland-related loans fell to 2.38% at the end of 2024 from 2.58% at the end of 2023. Banks’ provisions remained adequate. As at the end of 2024, banks’ credit provision coverage ratio (i.e. credit provisions and classified loan ratio) was around 65%. After deducting the realisable value of collateral from non-performing loan balances, the adjusted credit provision coverage ratio of banks was around 145%. Meanwhile, the delinquency ratios for residential mortgage loans and credit card loans remained low at 0.11% and 0.35%, respectively, at the end of 2024 (Chart 6).

Chart 5 Asset quality of the banking sector
Source: HKMA

Chart 6 Delinquency ratios for residential mortgage loans and credit card loans
Source: HKMA

# Profitability Trends

Retail banks’ overall pre-tax operating profit increased by 8.4% in 2024, while the post-tax return on average assets rose to 0.93% from 0.88% in the same period (Chart 7). Profit growth was mainly driven by higher investment income from holdings for trading (+97.0%) and higher fee and commission income (+15.4%), but was partly offset by lower net interest income (–5.2%). Retail banks’ net interest margin narrowed to 1.52% in 2024 from 1.67% in 2023 (Chart 8). Meanwhile, retail banks’ cost-to-income ratio edged up to 39.2% in 2024 from 38.9% in 2023 (Chart 9).

Chart 7 Performance of retail banks
Source: HKMA

Chart 8 Net interest margin of retail banks
Source: HKMA

Chart 9 Cost-to-income ratio of retail banks
Source: HKMA

# Balance Sheet Trends

The banking sector’s balance sheet expanded by 4.3% in 2024, mainly driven by an increase in transferable debt instruments (+13.4%). As borrowing costs remained high, loan demand was subdued, and total loans decreased by 2.8% in 2024. Of these, loans used in Hong Kong and loans used outside Hong Kong decreased by 2.1% and 5.7%, respectively, while trade finance increased by 4.6%. Mainland-related loans decreased by 8.7% in 2024.

On the liability side of the balance sheet, total deposits increased by 7.1% in 2024, compared with a 5.1% increase in 2023. As total loans decreased and total deposits increased, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio fell to 57.0% at the end of 2024 from 62.8% at the end of 2023 (Chart 10).

# Capital Adequacy

The banking sector maintained ample capital in 2024. The consolidated total capital ratio of locally incorporated authorised institutions was 21.8% at the end of 2024, compared with 21.1% a year earlier; the Tier 1 capital ratio was 19.9% (Chart 11). Both ratios were well above the relevant international minimum requirements. The Basel III leverage ratio was 8.0% at the end of 2024 (Chart 12).

Source: HKMA

Chart 11 Consolidated capital ratios of locally incorporated authorised institutions
Source: HKMA

Chart 12 Consolidated leverage ratio of locally incorporated authorised institutions
Source: HKMA

# Liquidity Position

The banking sector’s liquidity position remained robust. The quarterly average liquidity coverage ratio of Category 1 institutions was 178.4% in the fourth quarter of 2024, and the quarterly average liquidity maintenance ratio of Category 2 institutions was 67.0% (Chart 13). Customer deposits remained the banking sector’s main source of funds. As at the end of 2024, the stable funding net amount ratio of Category 1 institutions and the core funding ratio of Category 2A institutions were 143.4% and 186.7%, respectively (Chart 14). All four of these ratios were well above the statutory minimum requirements.

# 貨幣穩定

儘管美國貨幣政策走向、環球增長前景及地緣政治局勢緊張存在不明朗因素港元外匯及貨幣市場繼續保持暢順有序。港元匯率在2024年首四個月回軟，然後在年內其餘時間轉強。在聯繫匯率制度下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率的走勢，同時亦受本地供求情況影響。作為香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石，聯繫匯率制度一直展現強大抵禦外來衝擊的能力。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：

- 負債證明書（為三間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）；
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣；
- 設於金管局的結算戶口結餘總額（即總結餘）；及
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。當強方（或弱方）兌換保證被觸發，金管局會應銀行要求，按每美元兌7.75港元向銀行沽出港元、買入美元（或按7.85港元買入港元、沽出美元），使總結餘增加（或減少），令港元利率下跌（或上升），從而促使港元匯率回復到7.75至7.85的兌換範圍。

# 2024年回顧

# 匯率穩定

在2024年首四個月，港元隨着流動性回軟而稍為轉弱。在4月下旬至5月中期間，主要在股息相關資金需求及股票市場交投活躍的支持下，港元匯率轉強。在8月初，由於市場一度憂慮美國經濟可能出現衰退，以及預期美國聯邦儲備局將以更快及更大幅度減息，觸發套息交易平倉及港元短倉平倉，使港元轉強至兌換保證範圍的強方。港元在9月下旬進一步走強，受惠於內地公布一系列經濟刺激措施後，本港股市交投急增。港元其後於11月初稍為轉弱，部分由於本港股市的升幅有所回落，部分則由於其時美國經濟表現強勁，給予聯邦公開市場委員會空間謹慎地調低聯邦基金利率所致。其後港元在年底季節性資金需求帶動下回升。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2024年全年繼續運作正常（圖1）。

圖 1 2024年市場匯率

由於年內並無觸發兌換保證，總結餘變動不大，維持在447億港元左右。與此同時，未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由12,455億港元，稍增至13,839億港元。因此，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由2023 年底的 12,904 億港元，增加至 2024 年底的 14,287億港元（圖2）。整體貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

# 貨幣市場

在聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率走勢，當中短期拆息亦受本地供求情況影響。隨着市場對美國政策利率下調的預期逐漸升溫，香港銀行同業拆息在2024年首八個月大致回軟（圖3）。在季末季節性資金需求及股市交投活躍的推動下，香港銀行同業拆息於9月下旬收緊，隔夜拆息於季末更一度升至6厘以上。其後香港銀行同業拆息大致穩定，至年底前因流動性相對減少而上升。全年計，隔夜、一個月及三個月香港銀行同業拆息分別下跌45、69及78基點至年底時的5.65厘、4.58厘及4.37厘。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標區間下調，基本利率下調三次，合共一個百分點（即100基點），由5.75厘下跌至4.75厘（圖3）。在零售層面，隨着美國下調政策利率，多間銀行在9月中調低最優惠貸款利率25基點，並在11月初及12月下旬分別再調低25基點及12.5基點。在此情況下，新造按揭貸款平均利率亦由2023年的4.13厘下跌至2024年12月的3.59厘。整體而言，香港貨幣市場繼續正常運作。貼現窗借貸由2023年的388億港元增至2024年的500億港元；貼現窗的使用情況未見異常。

圖 3 2024年香港銀行同業拆息

# 聯繫匯率制度

自1983年以來，聯匯制度一直是香港金融體系的重要支柱，展現強大應對挑戰的能力。儘管美國政策利率走向存在不確定因素，以及地緣經濟碎片化，港元外匯及貨幣市場維持有序運作，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。政府亦堅決維持聯匯制度。國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在《2024年對外部門報告》一再重申香港擁有具透明度的規則、龐大的財政及外匯儲備、穩健的金融規管與監管、靈活的經濟，以及審慎的財政架構，確保聯匯制度具公信力。

穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用。香港銀行體系繼續運作暢順，流動性及資本狀況以國際標準而言均非常充裕。為確保銀行體系具備抵禦衝擊的能力，金管局一直密切監察銀行的信用、流動性與利率風險管理，以及壓力測試結果，並維持對銀行貸款的監管。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）由2023年底的110.73%上升至2024年9月10日的112.65%高位，超出112.5%的觸發上限（圖4），當中主要來自投資的利息及投資按市價重估。按照外匯基金諮詢委員會批准的安排，從支持組合轉撥資產至投資組合，令支持比率於9月11日降至110.08%左右。其後支持比率大致保持穩定，於12月31日收報109.56%。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，加上香港穩健的銀行體系，為保障香港的貨幣及金融穩定提供強而有力的後盾。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的貨幣發行委員會負責監察及探討與香港貨幣及金融穩定有關的課題。在2024年，貨幣發行委員會探討的課題包括香港銀行業對非銀行金融機構的風險承擔，以及主要先進經濟體的最新貨幣政策實施框架。貨幣發行委員會會議紀錄及金管局向其呈交的貨幣發行局制度運作報告，均載於金管局網站。

# Monetary stability

Despite uncertainties surrounding the direction of US monetary policy, global growth prospects and geopolitical tensions, Hong Kong’s foreign exchange and monetary markets have remained smooth and orderly. The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate weakened in the first four months of 2024, then strengthened for the remainder of the year. Under the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong interbank rates generally follow the trend of US dollar interest rates, while also being influenced by local supply and demand conditions. As the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, the linked exchange rate system has consistently demonstrated a strong ability to resist external shocks.

# Objective

The primary objective of Hong Kong’s monetary policy is to maintain monetary stability by ensuring the stability of the Hong Kong dollar’s exchange rate, which is kept within the range of 7.75 to 7.85 Hong Kong dollars per US dollar in the foreign exchange market. This monetary system operates under a currency board arrangement, which mandates that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund provide at least 100% backing to the monetary base. If the monetary base changes, the US dollar reserves must be adjusted accordingly, fully matching the changes in the monetary base.

The monetary base (Table 1) comprises:

- certificates of indebtedness, which fully support the banknotes issued by the three note-issuing banks;
- banknotes and coins issued by the government and in circulation;
- the total balance of settlement accounts held at the Monetary Authority (i.e. the aggregate balance); and
- Exchange Fund notes and bonds issued by the Monetary Authority on behalf of the government.

**Table 1: Monetary Base**

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through an automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and a firm commitment to honouring its exchange guarantee. When the strong-side (or weak-side) exchange guarantee is triggered, the HKMA, at the request of banks, sells Hong Kong dollars to banks at a rate of HK$7.75 per US dollar and buys US dollars (or buys Hong Kong dollars at HK$7.85 and sells US dollars). This increases (or decreases) the aggregate balance, causing Hong Kong dollar interest rates to fall (or rise), thereby prompting the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate to return to the range of 7.75 to 7.85.

# 2024 in Review

# Exchange Rate Stability

In the first four months of 2024, the Hong Kong dollar weakened slightly as liquidity softened. From late April to mid-May, the currency strengthened, primarily supported by dividend-related funding needs and active trading in the stock market. In early August, concerns about a potential US recession and expectations of faster and more significant interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve triggered unwinding of carry trades and short positions in the Hong Kong dollar, causing it to strengthen to the upper limit of its exchange guarantee range. The Hong Kong dollar further strengthened in late September, benefiting from a surge in local stock market trading following the mainland’s announcement of a series of economic stimulus measures. The currency then weakened slightly in early November, partly due to a decline in gains in the local stock market and partly because strong US economic performance gave the Federal Open Market Committee room to cautiously lower the federal funds rate. The Hong Kong dollar subsequently rebounded, driven by seasonal funding demand at year-end. Overall, the Hong Kong foreign exchange market continued to operate normally throughout 2024 (Chart 1).

Chart 1 Market exchange rates in 2024

Since no conversion guarantee was triggered during the year, the aggregate balance remained largely unchanged, at around HK$447 billion. Meanwhile, the total outstanding Exchange Fund notes and bonds increased slightly, from HK$12,455 billion to HK$13,839 billion. As a result, the aggregate balance and the total outstanding Exchange Fund notes and bonds increased from HK$12,904 billion at the end of 2023 to HK$14,287 billion at the end of 2024 (Chart 2). The overall monetary base continues to be fully supported by foreign exchange reserves.

Chart 2 Aggregate balance in 2024 (before discount window activities) and outstanding Exchange Fund notes and bonds

# Money Market

Under the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong interbank offered rates generally follow the trend of US dollar interest rates, with short-term rates also influenced by local supply and demand conditions. As market expectations for a reduction in US policy rates gradually increased, Hong Kong interbank offered rates softened over the first eight months of 2024 (Chart 3). Driven by seasonal funding demand at the end of the quarter and active stock market trading, Hong Kong interbank offered rates tightened in late September, with overnight rates rising above 6% at quarter-end. Thereafter, Hong Kong interbank offered rates were broadly stable, before rising towards the end of the year due to relatively reduced liquidity. Over the year as a whole, overnight, one-month and three-month Hong Kong interbank offered rates fell by 45, 69 and 78 basis points respectively to 5.65%, 4.58% and 4.37% at year-end.

In response to a reduction in the target range for the US federal funds rate, the base rate was lowered three times by a total of one percentage point (i.e., 100 basis points), falling from 5.75% to 4.75% (Figure 3). At the retail level, following the US policy rate cuts, several banks lowered their prime lending rates by 25 basis points in mid-September, with further reductions of 25 basis points and 12.5 basis points in early November and late December, respectively. Under these circumstances, the average interest rate for new mortgage loans also decreased from 4.13% in 2023 to 3.59% in December 2024. Overall, Hong Kong’s monetary market continued to function normally. Discount window borrowing increased from HKD 38.8 billion in 2023 to HKD 50 billion in 2024, with no abnormalities observed in its usage.

Figure 3: Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (HIBOR) in 2024

# Linked Exchange Rate System

Since 1983, the linked exchange rate system has been a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s financial system, demonstrating a strong ability to cope with challenges. Despite uncertainties surrounding the direction of US policy interest rates and the issue of geoeconomic fragmentation, Hong Kong’s foreign exchange and monetary markets have continued to operate in an orderly manner. This reflects the robustness and effectiveness of the linked exchange rate system. The government remains firmly committed to maintaining this system. In its 2024 External Sector Report, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) reiterated that Hong Kong possesses transparent rules, substantial fiscal and foreign exchange reserves, robust financial regulation and supervision, a flexible economy, and a prudent fiscal framework, all of which ensure the credibility of the linked exchange rate system.

A robust banking system is critical to the normal functioning of the linked exchange rate system. Hong Kong’s banking system continues to operate smoothly, with liquidity and capital conditions being very robust by international standards. To ensure that the banking system has the ability to withstand shocks, the HKMA has been closely monitoring banks’ credit, liquidity and interest rate risk management, as well as stress test results, and maintaining supervision of bank lending.

To enhance the transparency of the currency board accounts, part of the Exchange Fund’s assets have been designated to back the monetary base since October 1998. The backing ratio (i.e. the ratio of backing assets to the monetary base) rose from 110.73% at the end of 2023 to a high of 112.65% on 10 September 2024, exceeding the trigger limit of 112.5% (Chart 4). This was mainly due to interest earned from investments and the revaluation of investments at market prices. In accordance with the arrangements approved by the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, assets were transferred from the backing portfolio to the investment portfolio, bringing the backing ratio down to around 110.08% on 11 September. The ratio then remained broadly stable, closing at 109.56% on 31 December. Under the linked exchange rate system, although certain Exchange Fund assets have been designated as the backing portfolio, all of the Exchange Fund’s assets can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The Exchange Fund’s vast financial resources, together with Hong Kong’s robust banking system, provide a strong safeguard for the city’s monetary and financial stability.

**Figure 4: Daily Changes in Support Ratio, 2024**

# Currency Issuance Committee

The Currency Board Committee, operating under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, is responsible for monitoring and exploring issues related to Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability. In 2024, the committee’s discussions focused on topics such as the risk exposure of Hong Kong’s banking sector to non-bank financial institutions, as well as the latest monetary policy implementation frameworks adopted by major advanced economies. The meeting minutes of the Currency Board Committee and the reports on the operation of the Currency Board System submitted by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) to the committee are available on the HKMA’s website.

# Hong Kong Banknotes

Over the course of the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority held 14 seminars on the design and anti-counterfeiting features of Hong Kong banknotes, attracting more than 2,600 participants, including bank counter staff, retail cashiers, and students. These seminars helped to improve their knowledge and skills in identifying banknotes.

# Coin Collection Programme

The coin collection programme remains popular with the public. Details of the programme are set out in the chapter on 'The HKMA and Sustainable Development' in the 2024 Sustainable Development Report.

# US Dollar Liquidity Arrangements

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced enhancements to the US dollar liquidity arrangement, including shortening the settlement cycle from T+1 to T+0, effective from 24 May. This standing liquidity facility can provide reserve liquidity to licensed banks when needed, particularly given that the United States will begin implementing a shortened T+1 settlement cycle on 28 May.

# Exchange Fund Notes and Bonds

The Exchange Fund Notes and Bonds Programme continued to operate smoothly. As at the end of 2024, the outstanding Exchange Fund Notes and Bonds had a nominal total value of approximately HK$13,068 billion (Table 2).

# Monetary Research

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary and Financial Research Centre (the Research Centre), which is responsible for research under the Financial Academy, published 15 research papers on monetary and financial topics of strategic importance to Hong Kong and the wider region. It also shared its findings with a global audience through five issues of an open-access electronic journal. The Research Centre also published two editions of *Insights from Monetary Research*, providing the public with high-level, non-technical summaries of its recently published research papers.

In addition to its research work, the research centre organises a series of knowledge exchange activities to facilitate connections with different participants. During the year, 31 seminars or webinars were held for local participants to discuss important currency and financial research issues. At the international level, the School of Finance and the Research Centre, in collaboration with academic institutions, central banks and international financial institutions, organised four international conferences and five seminars or roundtable meetings to promote dialogue and exchange on a wide range of economic and financial issues.

# 銀行體系穩定

儘管面對宏觀經濟挑戰及地緣政治的不確定性，香港銀行體系在2024年維持穩健。金管局迅速採取措施支援本地中小型企業，並透過風險為本監管與應變規劃保障銀行體系穩定，另又提供監管指引及支持業界應對新生風險，以提升銀行業的運作穩健性與網絡防衛韌性。為鼓勵應用金融科技，金管局推出連串跨行業項目，包括生成式人工智能「沙盒」。

金管局推出《保障消費者防詐騙約章2.0》，以加強銀行消費者保障。我們又推出「智安存」協助存款人有效保護存款，以及有關銀行無抵押消費信貸產品的冷靜期以減低衝動及過度借貸的風險。此外，金管局向銀行提供有關在面向客戶的服務中應用生成式人工智能的指引，又就二手物業買賣交易提供多一種支付安排與業界緊密合作。金管局亦透過發出數碼資產相關活動的指引、優化「跨境理財通」業務試點，以及簡化銷售投資及保險產品程序，提升客戶體驗，並同時確保投資者保障。年內完成個人信貸資料服務全面過渡至「信資通」。

金管局在香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集制度方面扮演重要角色。透過提高經由反訛騙及洗黑錢情報工作組交換情報的速度及數量，與2023年相比，情報主導的可疑交易報告增加303%，促使凍結或充公的犯罪得益增加34%。有關促進銀行分享訊息以協助偵測及防止金融罪行的法例修訂的諮詢得到廣泛支持。金管局在4月根據交易監察系統專題審查結果提供指引，以及在9月推出計劃促進業界應用人工智能監察可疑活動。金管局亦與銀行業及香港警務處合作，優化「可疑帳號警示」機制及加強宣傳工作，並就防範、偵測及制止授權支付詐騙向銀行發出指引。

香港在實施包括資本充足及披露等國際監管標準方面取得良好進展。香港存款保障委員會優化了存款保障計劃的多個範疇，以加強對存款人的保障。

為確保處置機制具公信力，金管局實施處置標準，規定銀行須更新與對手方的金融合約，減低處置中的提前終止風險。此外，金管局在制定銀行的首選處置策略、應對處置可行性障礙以確保有足夠財政資源及處置中的運作持續性，以及提升處置執行能力方面均取得顯著進展。

# 目標

金管局的目標之一是促進銀行體系的安全及穩定。要達致這個目標，實有賴建立及維持具高度應對能力且能為香港經濟提供所需關鍵金融服務的金融體系。

銀行可能因其營運方式，甚或在極端情況下因失序地倒閉而影響金融體系的穩定。作為監管當局，金融管理專員在保障金融穩定方面擔當重要角色，確保銀行有能力抵禦衝擊及應對危機，以最終有助防止出現倒閉。金融管理專員負責對銀行進行審慎監管，以及認可香港的持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司（統稱「認可機構」）。

香港的審慎監管制度並非為確保「零風險」而設。事實上，作為一個處置機制當局，金融管理專員力求確保一旦有認可機構不再可持續經營，能有秩序地處理其倒閉。為此，香港已設立金融機構處置機制，金融管理專員在該機制下為認可機構的處置機制當局。為落實香港的處置機制，我們有必要制定處置規則及政策標準、進行處置規劃以排除認可機構處置可行性的障礙，以及建立金管局處置瀕臨倒閉認可機構的運作能力。為有效執行上述工作，金管局採納與國際一致及協調的方法。

金融管理專員亦負責指定及監察某些金融市場基建。金管局監察金融市場基建的目的，是促進有關基建的整體安全及效率、減低系統性風險，以及提高透明度。提升金融市場基建面對金融危機的抗震能力，能保障香港的貨幣與金融體系，避免因金融市場基建運作中斷而影響其穩定。

在2024年，金管局完成有關簡化銀行三級制至二級制的公眾諮詢，回應者普遍支持簡化建議。經考慮所收到的意見，金管局就建議提出若干新的關鍵事項，以精簡過渡過程及減少對接受存款公司現有客戶的影響。

金管局就於香港引入公司遷冊制度向政府提供支援，包括協助修訂《銀行業條例》及其附屬法例以及其他與金管局有關的法例的立法程序。

# Banking System Stability

Despite facing macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical uncertainties, Hong Kong’s banking system remained robust in 2024. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) took swift measures to support local small and medium-sized enterprises and safeguarded the stability of the banking system through risk-based regulation and contingency planning. It also provided regulatory guidance and support to help the industry address emerging risks, thereby enhancing the operational resilience and cyber defence capabilities of the banking sector. To encourage the application of financial technology, the HKMA launched a series of cross-industry projects, including a generative artificial intelligence sandbox.

The HKMA launched the Consumer Anti-Scam Protection Charter 2.0 to strengthen consumer protection in the banking sector. We also introduced SmartSafe Deposit to help depositors protect their deposits effectively, and a cooling-off period for unsecured consumer credit products offered by banks to reduce the risk of impulsive and excessive borrowing. In addition, the HKMA provided guidance to banks on the application of generative artificial intelligence in customer-facing services, and worked closely with the industry to provide an additional payment arrangement for second-hand property transactions. The HKMA also enhanced customer experience and ensured investor protection by issuing guidelines on digital asset-related activities, optimising the Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect pilot scheme, and simplifying the sales process for investment and insurance products. The full transition of the personal credit information service to the Credit Information Transmission System was completed during the year.

The HKMA plays an important role in Hong Kong’s anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regime. By increasing the speed and volume of intelligence exchanged through the Anti-Deception and Anti-Money Laundering Intelligence Taskforce, intelligence-led suspicious transaction reports increased by 303% compared to 2023, leading to a 34% increase in the amount of criminal proceeds frozen or confiscated. The consultation on legislative amendments to facilitate information sharing among banks to help detect and prevent financial crimes received widespread support. In April, the HKMA issued guidance based on the findings of a thematic review of transaction monitoring systems, and in September, it launched a programme to promote the use of artificial intelligence by the industry to monitor suspicious activities. The HKMA also worked with the banking sector and the Hong Kong Police Force to enhance the Suspicious Account Alert mechanism and strengthen publicity efforts, and issued guidance to banks on preventing, detecting and disrupting authorised payment scams.

Hong Kong has made good progress in implementing international regulatory standards, including those on capital adequacy and disclosure. The Hong Kong Deposit Protection Board has enhanced various aspects of the deposit protection scheme to strengthen protection for depositors.

To ensure the credibility of the resolution regime, the HKMA implemented resolution standards requiring banks to update their financial contracts with counterparties to reduce the risk of early termination in resolution. In addition, the HKMA made significant progress in developing banks’ preferred resolution strategies, addressing resolution feasibility obstacles to ensure sufficient financial resources and operational continuity in resolution, and enhancing resolution execution capabilities.

# Objectives

One of the HKMA’s objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. Achieving this objective relies on establishing and maintaining a financial system with a high degree of resilience that can provide the critical financial services needed by the Hong Kong economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the financial system due to their mode of operation, or even, in extreme cases, due to disorderly failure. As a regulator, the Commissioner of Financial Management plays an important role in safeguarding financial stability by ensuring that banks have the ability to withstand shocks and manage crises, ultimately helping to prevent failures. The Commissioner of Financial Management is responsible for prudential supervision of banks and for authorising licensed banks, restricted licence banks and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong (collectively referred to as “authorised institutions”).

Hong Kong’s prudential regulatory regime is not designed to ensure zero risk. In fact, as a resolution authority, the Commissioner of Financial Management seeks to ensure that if an authorised institution is no longer viable, its failure can be handled in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution regime, under which the Commissioner of Financial Management is the resolution authority for authorised institutions. To implement Hong Kong’s resolution regime, it is necessary for us to develop resolution rules and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove obstacles to the resolvability of authorised institutions, and build the HKMA’s operational capability to resolve authorised institutions that are on the verge of failure. To effectively carry out the above work, the HKMA adopts an internationally consistent and coordinated approach.

The Commissioner of Financial Management is also responsible for designating and supervising certain financial market infrastructures. The HKMA’s supervision of financial market infrastructures aims to promote the overall safety and efficiency of such infrastructures, reduce systemic risk, and enhance transparency. Enhancing the resilience of financial market infrastructures to financial crises safeguards Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system by avoiding disruptions to the stability of the financial market infrastructures due to operational failures.

# Review of 2024

# Licensing matters

During the year, the HKMA granted banking licences to one bank incorporated in Hong Kong and one bank incorporated outside Hong Kong. The HKMA also approved a dealer broker outside Hong Kong to become a money broker. In addition, the HKMA revoked the authorisation of three licensed banks, one restricted licence bank and one deposit-taking company during the year.

For more information on Hong Kong’s authorised institutions and local representative offices, please refer to the appendices and Tables D to F on pages 311 to 314 and 320 to 323 respectively.

# Review of the three-tier banking system

In 2024, the HKMA completed a public consultation on simplifying the three-tier banking system to a two-tier system, and respondents generally supported the simplification proposal. After considering the views received, the HKMA proposed several new key elements to streamline the transition process and reduce the impact on existing customers of deposit-taking companies.

# Renaming of virtual banks

In addition, the HKMA completed a public consultation on renaming “virtual banks” to “digital banks”. The renaming proposal received widespread support, and the HKMA revised the statutory guideline on the authorisation of digital banks in October, when the proposal took effect.

# Review of digital banks

Another task completed in 2024 was a comprehensive review of digital banks, with the review report published in August. The review showed that digital banks have achieved the three policy objectives of introducing digital banks in Hong Kong, namely promoting financial technology and innovation, providing new customer experiences, and promoting financial inclusion. With the diversified development of digital banks and traditional banks, the HKMA considers that the current number of digital bank licences is appropriate and there is no need to introduce more new digital bank participants to the market at this stage. The revised guideline on the authorisation of digital banks issued in October relaxed several restrictions on the industry, including allowing digital banks to conduct banking business other than retail banking, and to establish physical branches if it is reasonable from a customer experience and business strategy perspective, provided that digital banks continue to provide banking services primarily through digital channels.

# Review of banking licence fees

The HKMA completed a review of licence fees during the year and raised the fee levels in June.

# Hong Kong’s company redomiciliation regime

The HKMA provided support to the government on the introduction of a company redomiciliation regime in Hong Kong, including assisting in the legislative process to amend the Banking Ordinance and its subsidiary legislation, as well as other legislation related to the HKMA.

# Overview of regulatory work

During the year, the HKMA conducted 174 off-site inspections covering a wide range of areas, including CAMEL assessments, corporate governance and risk management of authorised institutions. To further enhance the risk governance level of authorised institutions, the HKMA held 36 meetings with the boards of authorised institutions, independent non-executive directors or board committees, and 38 tripartite meetings with authorised institutions and their external auditors. In addition, the HKMA conducted on-site inspections of various businesses of authorised institutions, including governance and practices in credit, market and liquidity risk management.

Given the increasing use of technology by authorised institutions, operational risk and technology risk management are another regulatory focus. The HKMA also further strengthened its supervision of authorised institutions’ climate risk management to enhance their ability to cope with climate change. The HKMA’s work in maintaining financial stability and promoting robust economic growth in an uncertain global economic environment was recognised, and it was awarded Best Macroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific by The Asian Banker magazine.

Assistant President (Banking Supervision) Ms Julia Leung (centre) represented the HKMA in receiving the Best Macroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific award from The Asian Banker magazine.

In terms of conduct supervision, the HKMA conducted on-site inspections of authorised institutions’ securities, investment products, trust, insurance and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF)-related businesses, as well as consumer protection matters, and complemented these with thematic assessments to review new projects or areas assessed as higher risk.

SMEs are an important cornerstone of Hong Kong’s economy, and the HKMA has been closely monitoring their access to bank financing. In 2024, the HKMA and the banking sector introduced more measures to support SMEs whose business operations still face challenges due to economic transformation, and to help SMEs continue to grow and upgrade.

# New SME support measures

Through the SME Coordination Mechanism, the HKMA introduced nine measures in March to help SMEs access bank financing and support their continued development.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局於2024年在加強香港作為具全球競爭力的國際金融中心的地位方面取得重要進展。

金管局與內地及香港有關當局合作，推出一系列措施，共同深化及擴展香港與內地金融市場的互聯互通，包括優化「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」；擴大金管局人民幣流動資金安排及「北向互換通」的合資格抵押品範圍；優化「北向互換通」；以及優化一級流動性提供行安排。這些措施有助強化香港的門戶角色，並鞏固其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位

金管局在鞏固香港金融平台的競爭力方面亦取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、綠色和可持續金融，以及企業財資中心等範疇。為宣傳香港的金融服務，金管局加強面向海外及內地持份者的市場推廣工作，讓大家充分認識香港金融體系的穩健及其帶來的機遇。第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」及多項其他盛事成功舉辦，不僅有助提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的形象，更製造正面的漣漪效應。金管局積極參與多個國際及區內的央行及監管組織，繼續對維持金融穩定及促進金融市場發展的全球工作作出貢獻。

金管局在「金融科技2025」 策略的各個範疇均取得顯著進展，包括央行數碼貨幣及數據基建。

快速支付系統「轉數快」的登記數目及交易量繼續穩步增長，於2024年底達到1,580萬個登記，全年平均每日處理港元即時交易增至165萬宗。金管局正與中國人民銀行緊密合作，推動落實香港「轉數快」與內地網上支付跨行清算系統互聯，實現跨境支付。

# 概覽

在2024年，金管局繼續致力提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

金管局擴展及優化香港與內地間的互聯互通機制，有助鞏固香港作為內地與國際金融市場間的橋樑角色。年內，多項有關「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）的優化措施出台，便利粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）個人投資者進行跨境投資。於2月，金管局將中華人民共和國財政部（國家財政部）發行的在岸國債和內地政策性銀行發行的政策性金融債納入人民幣流動資金安排的合資格抵押品名單。於7月，兩地相關部門公布進一步支持境外投資者使用通過「債券通」持有的在岸債券作為「北向互換通」交易的履約抵押品，並於2025年1月實施。此外，「北向互換通」於年內進行優化，增加投資者在對沖策略和管理投資組合方面的靈活性及效率。

在2024年，香港的離岸人民幣業務穩健增長。金管局推出一級流動性提供行安排的優化措施，包括增加提供行數目及擴大安排規模。於年底前，香港人民幣即時支付結算系統的夜間跨境服務能力提升，以更好應付全球各地對跨境人民幣支付的需要。

金管局推出大灣區金融合作下的多項利民便商措施，包括促進企業跨境融資的跨境徵信互通業務試點，以及便利香港居民在大灣區置業的跨境匯款支付安排。

金管局繼續致力提升香港整體金融平台的競爭力。具體而言，為增強香港作為首選基金管理中心及家族辦公室業務樞紐的吸引力，金管局與政府及金融業緊密合作，締造更便利的稅務及監管環境。此外，金管局透過Evergreen項目發行第二批代幣化債券，並推出「EvergreenHub」一站式數碼債券知識庫和「數碼債券資助計劃」，繼續推動香港債券市場創新。於10月，金管局公布「可持續金融行動計劃」，訂明進一步鞏固香港作為區內綠色和可持續金融樞紐的具體目標。

另一方面，金管局繼續加強市場拓展工作，向海外及內地持份者介紹香港的金融服務。金管局在11月舉辦第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，主題為「在變局中前航」，雲集全球各地金融業界翹楚分享各自獨到的觀點。峰會先由國務院副總理何立峰先生作開幕主題演講，接着是三間內地金融監管機構的分享環節，以及由國際金融領袖參與的專題討論。峰會共匯聚350多位來自超過120間國際金融機構的領袖參與，充分體現國際金融界對香港的支持和信心。

年內金管局亦舉辦各項其他研討會及會議，包括：

- 於9月與迪拜金融服務管理局合辦聯合氣候金融會議；
- 於10月與全球風險管理專業人士協會合辦第15屆全球風險論壇；
- 於10月亦與國際結算銀行合辦國際金融研討會；及
- 於12月舉辦金融穩定理事會全體會議，是自2016年以來首次在亞洲舉行的同類會議，匯聚超過50個國家財政金融機關及12個國際標準制定機構的領袖和高級官員。

年內金管局亦積極加強與其他地區的雙邊聯繫。於12月，金管局分別與阿拉伯聯合酋長國中央銀行（阿聯酋央行）及沙特中央銀行（沙特央行）在香港舉行雙邊會議，促進中東與亞洲地區之間的投資及金融市場聯繫。金管局與阿聯酋央行簽署諒解備忘錄，建立兩地債務資本市場基建的互聯互通，並促進跨境債務證券發行及投資活動。在此之前，金管局於10月訪問卡塔爾多哈，加強兩地金融服務領域的合作。

此外，金管局於12月舉行第七次香港與瑞士金融合作對話，討論內容涵蓋區內及本地的前景與政策挑戰，以及可持續金融、金融科技與市場互聯互通領域的最新發展及潛在合作空間。

金管局分別於1月及5月訪問泰國和馬來西亞，與中央銀行、金融機構和企業會面，推廣香港作為國際金融中心的地位，並進一步加強雙邊金融聯繫和合作。重點領域之一是推廣使用人民幣和本地貨幣作跨境投資和貿易結算，以及香港的競爭優勢。

在國際層面，金管局積極參與中央銀行領域的事務，並繼續在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色。金管局現為巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下政策及標準小組和金融穩定理事會轄下亞洲區域諮詢小組的聯席主席，另又擔任金融穩定理事會轄下金融創新網絡聯席主席（至2024年7月止）。金管局亦為國際結算銀行轄下主要新興市場經濟體行長會議和金融穩定理事會轄下加密資產框架同業評審小組的主席。在2018至2024年間，金管局一直連任東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP)轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

金管局金融科技促進辦公室與各銀行部門繼續實施「金融科技2025」策略，促進業界廣泛採用金融科技，並提升香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位。年內推行的主要措施包括：

- 進一步推動銀行在五個主要範疇的金融科技應用，包括財富科技、保險科技、綠色科技、人工智能及分布式分類帳技術；
- 推動央行數碼貨幣的工作，以了解其效益及潛在的應用場景，包括：
    - 推進「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目，以改善跨境支付；
    - 進一步研究在香港發行「數碼港元」(e-HKD)的可行性；及
    - 開始探索以央行數碼貨幣支持香港代幣化市場的發展；
- 透過「商業數據通」便利中小企借貸；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；及
- 推動更廣泛使用快速支付系統「轉數快」。

「轉數快」的使用在2024年繼續增加，登記數目與交易量在過去六年穩步上升。截至2024年底，「轉數快」登記數目增至1,580萬個，全年每日平均交易宗數較上年上升33%。除個人對個人支付及商業支付穩步增長外，透過「轉數快」繳付政府帳單、支付予商戶及為儲值支付工具電子錢包或銀行帳戶增值持續增加，是帶動「轉數快」交易量持續增長的主要原因。

為確保本地零售支付業的安全及效率，金管局根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）監察六個指定零售支付系統，並監管15項持牌儲值支付工具（其中四項由持牌銀行發行）。年內金管局繼續與業界緊密合作，因應詐騙風險上升加強管控措施及保障消費者。

財經事務及庫務局與金管局就在香港實施穩定幣發行人監管制度的立法建議，於2月完成為期兩個月的公眾諮詢後，於7月聯合發表諮詢總結，並於12月將《穩定幣條例草案》提交立法會審議。為更了解穩定幣發行人的業務模式，並制定適切的監管制度，金管局亦推出穩定幣發行人「沙盒」，並於7月公布三間進入「沙盒」的參與機構。與此同時，金管局繼續積極參與國際組織在數碼資產相關課題（包括穩定幣及代幣化）的工作，確保相關監管框架符合國際標準及最佳做法。

# Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) made significant progress in strengthening Hong Kong’s position as a globally competitive international financial centre.

The HKMA worked with relevant authorities in mainland China and Hong Kong to launch a series of measures aimed at jointly deepening and expanding the interconnectivity between Hong Kong and mainland financial markets. These measures included optimising the “Wealth Management Connect” scheme in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area; expanding the scope of eligible collateral under the HKMA’s Renminbi Liquidity Facility and Northbound Swap Connect; optimising Northbound Swap Connect; and enhancing the Primary Liquidity Provider Scheme. These initiatives helped reinforce Hong Kong’s role as a gateway and consolidate its position as a global offshore renminbi (RMB) business hub.

The HKMA also made good progress in enhancing the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform across various areas, including bond issuance, asset and wealth management, green and sustainable finance, and corporate treasury centres. To promote Hong Kong’s financial services, the HKMA stepped up its market outreach efforts targeting overseas and mainland stakeholders, helping them to fully understand the robustness of Hong Kong’s financial system and the opportunities it offers. The successful hosting of the third International Financial Leaders Investment Summit and several other major events not only helped to enhance Hong Kong’s image as a leading international financial centre but also created a positive ripple effect. The HKMA actively participated in multiple international and regional central bank and regulatory organisations, continuing to contribute to global efforts to maintain financial stability and promote financial market development.

The HKMA made significant progress in all areas of its “Fintech 2025” strategy, including central bank digital currency and data infrastructure.

The registration numbers and transaction volume of the Faster Payment System (FPS) continued to grow steadily, reaching 15.8 million registrations by the end of 2024. The average daily number of instant Hong Kong dollar transactions processed increased to 1.65 million throughout the year. The HKMA is working closely with the People’s Bank of China to promote the implementation of the interconnection between Hong Kong’s FPS and the mainland’s online interbank clearing system for web-based payments, enabling cross-border payments.

# Overview

In 2024, the HKMA continued its efforts to enhance Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international financial centre.

The HKMA expanded and optimised the interconnectivity mechanisms between Hong Kong and mainland China, helping to reinforce Hong Kong’s role as a bridge between the mainland and international financial markets. During the year, several optimisation measures related to the “Wealth Management Connect” scheme in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area were introduced to facilitate cross-border investment by individual investors. In February, the HKMA added onshore government bonds issued by the Ministry of Finance of the People’s Republic of China and policy bank bonds issued by mainland policy banks to the list of eligible collateral under the Renminbi Liquidity Facility. In July, relevant authorities in both regions announced further support for offshore investors to use onshore bonds held through Bond Connect as collateral for Northbound Swap Connect transactions, with implementation scheduled for January 2025. Additionally, Northbound Swap Connect was optimised during the year to increase investors’ flexibility and efficiency in hedging strategies and portfolio management.

In 2024, Hong Kong’s offshore RMB business grew steadily. The HKMA introduced enhancements to the Primary Liquidity Provider Scheme, including increasing the number of providers and expanding the scale of the scheme. By year-end, the cross-border service capacity of Hong Kong’s RMB Real-Time Gross Settlement system during night-time hours was improved to better meet global demand for cross-border RMB payments.

Under the Greater Bay Area financial cooperation framework, the HKMA launched several measures to benefit individuals and businesses, including a pilot cross-border credit information sharing service to facilitate cross-border financing for enterprises and a cross-border remittance payment arrangement to make it easier for Hong Kong residents to purchase property in the Greater Bay Area.

The HKMA continued its efforts to enhance the overall competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform. Specifically, to strengthen Hong Kong’s attractiveness as a preferred fund management centre and family office hub, the HKMA worked closely with the government and the financial industry to create a more favourable tax and regulatory environment. Furthermore, the HKMA issued a second batch of tokenised bonds through the Evergreen project and launched the “EvergreenHub” one-stop digital bond knowledge repository and the “Digital Bond Grant Scheme” to continue driving innovation in Hong Kong’s bond market. In October, the HKMA announced the “Sustainable Finance Action Plan”, setting out specific goals to further consolidate Hong Kong’s position as a regional hub for green and sustainable finance.

Meanwhile, the HKMA continued to strengthen its market outreach efforts, promoting Hong Kong’s financial services to overseas and mainland stakeholders. In November, the HKMA hosted the third International Financial Leaders Investment Summit. The three-day summit, themed “Navigating Through Change”, brought together financial leaders from around the world to share their unique insights. The summit began with an opening keynote speech by Mr He Lifeng, Deputy Prime Minister of the State Council, followed by presentations from three mainland financial regulators and panel discussions involving international financial leaders. The summit attracted over 350 leaders from more than 120 international financial institutions, demonstrating the international financial community’s strong support for and confidence in Hong Kong.

During the year, the HKMA also organised several other seminars and conferences, including:

- A joint climate finance conference co-hosted with the Dubai Financial Services Authority in September;
- The 15th Global Risk Forum, co-hosted with the Global Association of Risk Professionals in October;
- An international finance seminar co-hosted with the Bank for International Settlements in October; and
- The plenary meeting of the Financial Stability Board in December, the first such meeting held in Asia since 2016, which brought together leaders and senior officials from over 50 national financial authorities and 12 international standard-setting bodies.

During the year, the HKMA also actively strengthened its bilateral ties with other regions. In December, the HKMA held bilateral meetings in Hong Kong with the Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates and the Saudi Central Bank to promote investment and financial market linkages between the Middle East and Asia. The HKMA signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Central Bank of the UAE to establish interconnectivity between the two regions’ debt capital market infrastructures and promote cross-border debt securities issuance and investment activities. Prior to that, the HKMA visited Doha, Qatar, in October to strengthen cooperation in the financial services sector between the two regions.

In addition, the HKMA held its seventh Hong Kong-Switzerland Financial Cooperation Dialogue in December. Discussions covered regional and local prospects and policy challenges, as well as the latest developments and potential areas for cooperation in sustainable finance, financial technology, and market connectivity.

In January and May, the HKMA visited Thailand and Malaysia respectively, meeting with central banks, financial institutions, and businesses to promote Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre and further strengthen bilateral financial ties and cooperation. One key area of focus was promoting the use of renminbi and local currencies for cross-border investment and trade settlement, as well as Hong Kong’s competitive advantages.

Internationally, the HKMA actively participates in central banking affairs and continues to play a leadership role in various regional and international committees. The HKMA is currently co-chair of the Policy and Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Basel Committee) and the Asia Regional Consultative Group under the Financial Stability Board, and also served as co-chair of the Financial Innovation Network under the Financial Stability Board until July 2024. The HKMA also chairs the Meeting of Governors of Major Emerging Market Economies under the Bank for International Settlements and the Peer Review Group on Crypto-Asset Framework under the Financial Stability Board. From 2018 to 2024, the HKMA consecutively chaired the Financial Markets Working Group under the Executives’ Meeting of East Asia and Pacific Central Banks (EMEAP).

The HKMA’s Fintech Facilitation Office continues to work with various banking sectors to implement the “Fintech 2025” strategy, promoting the widespread adoption of fintech in the industry and enhancing Hong Kong’s position as a fintech hub in Asia. Key measures implemented during the year include:

- Further promoting the application of fintech in five key areas by banks, including wealthtech, insurtech, green tech, artificial intelligence, and distributed ledger technology;
- Advancing work on central bank digital currencies to understand their benefits and potential use cases, including:
    - Advancing the “multi-CBDC cross-border network” (mBridge) project to improve cross-border payments;
    - Further studying the feasibility of issuing “e-HKD” (digital Hong Kong dollar) in Hong Kong; and

# 儲備管理

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。主要經濟體錄得穩定增長，而通脹亦回落至更接近政策目標的水平。多個主要央行陸續下調政策利率，有利投資環境。2024年全年計，外匯基金錄得2,188億港元的投資收入，投資回報率為5.2%。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(i) 保障資本；
(ii) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(iii) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(iv) 在符合上述(i)至(iii)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障外匯基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合架構及目標資產配置中反映（圖示1）。

圖示1 外匯基金的投資組合類別

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員經濟體的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的目標資產配置與其他資產類別的配置，按審慎的風險管理原則及資產組合多元化策略一起制定。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子，其存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的回報掛鈎，利率視乎實際資產配置而定。於2024年，投資組合與長期增長組合在未來基金的目標資產配置約為35：65。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責外匯基金的投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約70%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分內部管理的投資組合包括環球定息市場投資，並透過不同的衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約30%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產類別。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取外聘投資經理的市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，穩健的風險管理更見重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線，以實施有效的風險管理及管治。金管局定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），並設置風險管理程序，為策略性規劃及多元化投資工作提供穩健的框架。

# 負責任投資

金管局相信適度強調負責任投資及投資的可持續長期表現，可更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動涉及的環境、社會及管治(ESG)相關風險。為積極支持負責任投資，金管局已將ESG因素融入外匯基金的投資管理過程中，其指導性原則是：當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，一般會優先考慮ESG投資。有關金管局在負責任投資方面的工作，詳見《二零二四年可持續發展報告》之「負責任投資」一章。

# 外匯基金的表現

# 2024年的金融市場

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。

主要股票市場於2024年升幅顯著，當中美國股市在經濟和通脹基調大致向好和人工智能熱潮背景下，首三季升幅尤其突出。不過第4季市況因憂慮通脹升溫及債息上升等而變得波動並從高位回落，投資者亦轉趨審慎。內地和香港股市方面，受惠於中央在第3季出台的一系列刺激經濟和股市的政策措施，投資者信心有所好轉。然而市場認為實體經濟增長依然不明朗的情況下，兩地股市於第4季回軟。

環球債券市場在2024年的表現亦有較大波動。儘管主要央行大致確立減息的大方向，但減息的節奏和幅度年內出現多次轉變。及至第4季，市場開始注視美國2025年的財政政策，美國國債收益率季內大幅上升，債價受壓。

貨幣市場方面，美元兌其他主要貨幣於2024年，特別是第4季，因為息口走勢和美國經濟表現相對強勁而走強。

# Reserve Management

Global financial markets performed well overall in 2024. Major economies recorded stable growth, while inflation fell to levels closer to policy targets. Several major central banks successively lowered policy interest rates, creating a favourable investment environment. For the whole of 2024, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$218.8 billion, with a return on investment of 5.2%.

# The Exchange Fund

Under the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund is to influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar directly or indirectly. It may also be used to maintain the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, thereby maintaining Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the use and investment management of the Exchange Fund under the powers delegated and sub-delegated by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment objectives and portfolio structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has set the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:

(i) to safeguard capital;
(ii) to ensure that the overall monetary base is fully backed by highly liquid US dollar assets at all times;
(iii) to ensure that liquidity is sufficient to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(iv) to maximise investment returns within the constraints of (i) to (iii) above in order to preserve the long-term purchasing power of the Exchange Fund.

These objectives fully take into account the statutory purpose of the Exchange Fund and are reflected in the Fund’s portfolio structure and target asset allocation (Figure 1).

Figure 1 Investment portfolio categories of the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: the Backing Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Backing Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets to fully back the monetary base in accordance with the requirements of the Currency Board System. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in bond and equity markets of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) member economies to preserve the value and long-term purchasing power of assets.

To better manage risks and enhance medium- to long-term returns, the HKMA has prudently and progressively allocated part of the Exchange Fund’s assets to more diversified asset classes, including emerging market and Mainland bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure) and real estate, in a step-by-step manner. Emerging market and Mainland bonds and equities are held by the Investment Portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the Long-term Growth Portfolio. The target asset allocation of the Long-term Growth Portfolio and other asset classes is formulated together in accordance with prudent risk management principles and asset portfolio diversification strategies.

The Strategic Portfolio was established in 2007 and has been holding shares of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Government for strategic purposes on behalf of the Exchange Fund’s account. Due to its unique nature, this portfolio is not included in the assessment of the Exchange Fund’s investment performance.

# Deposits in the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund accepts deposits from the fiscal reserves, government funds and statutory bodies from time to time. Interest rates are generally linked to the performance of the Investment Portfolio, but the Future Fund is a major exception. Its deposit interest rate is linked to the returns of the Investment Portfolio and the Long-term Growth Portfolio, depending on the actual asset allocation. In 2024, the target asset allocation of the Investment Portfolio and the Long-term Growth Portfolio in the Future Fund was approximately 35:65.

# Investment process

The Exchange Fund’s investment process is based on both strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation is reflected in the investment benchmark, which represents the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guide and employs tactical asset allocation to achieve returns above the benchmark. Therefore, actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e. the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocation is called “tactical deviation”. The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits. The HKMA is authorised to determine the tactical asset allocation and set the allowable range for tactical deviations. Portfolio managers can manage positions within the allowable range of tactical deviations to profit from short-term market changes.

# Direct investment

The Exchange Fund Investment Office of the HKMA is responsible for the investment and related risk management functions of the Exchange Fund. The Office’s staff are responsible for directly managing about 70% of the Exchange Fund’s investments, including the entire Backing Portfolio and part of the Investment Portfolio. This internally managed portion of the portfolio includes global fixed income market investments and implements the Exchange Fund’s macro risk management strategy through various derivative instruments.

# External investment managers

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the HKMA also employs external investment managers to manage about 30% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special asset classes. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to utilise the best professional investment expertise in the market to invest the Exchange Fund and achieve sustainable returns. This enables the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as to learn from the market insights and specialised investment knowledge of external investment managers.

The expenses associated with employing external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction fees, withholding tax and other taxes. These expenses vary from year to year and are mainly influenced by market factors.

# Risk management and monitoring

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, robust risk management is even more important. The HKMA has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and has put in place a rigorous risk monitoring and compliance system. The HKMA has established a three-line defence for investment-related activities to implement effective risk management and governance. The HKMA regularly monitors major investment risk categories (including credit, market, liquidity and operational risks) and establishes risk management procedures to provide a robust framework for strategic planning and diversified investment efforts.

# Responsible investment

The HKMA believes that an appropriate emphasis on responsible investment and the sustainable long-term performance of investments can more effectively achieve the investment objectives of the Exchange Fund and reduce the environmental, social and governance (ESG) risks associated with investment activities. To actively support responsible investment, the HKMA has integrated ESG factors into the investment management process of the Exchange Fund. The guiding principle is that ESG investments will generally be prioritised when their risk-adjusted long-term returns are comparable to those of other investment projects. For more information on the HKMA’s work on responsible investment, please refer to the “Responsible Investment” chapter of the 2024 Sustainable Development Report.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial markets in 2024

Global financial markets performed well overall in 2024.

Major stock markets recorded significant gains in 2024. US equities performed particularly strongly in the first three quarters amid a broadly favourable economic and inflation backdrop and an artificial intelligence boom. However, market conditions became volatile in the fourth quarter and retreated from highs amid concerns over rising inflation and bond yields, and investors turned cautious. As for Mainland and Hong Kong equities, investor confidence improved following a series of policy measures introduced by the Central Government in the third quarter to stimulate the economy and the stock market. However, the two markets softened in the fourth quarter as the market considered that the outlook for real economic growth remained uncertain.

Global bond markets also experienced significant volatility in 2024. Although major central banks had broadly established a direction for rate cuts, the pace and scale of rate cuts changed several times during the year. By the fourth quarter, the market began to focus on US fiscal policy in 2025, and US Treasury yields rose sharply during the quarter, putting pressure on bond prices.

In the currency market, the US dollar strengthened against other major currencies in 2024, particularly in the fourth quarter, due to interest rate trends and the relatively strong performance of the US economy.

Table 1 shows the performance of major currencies, bond markets and stock markets in 2024.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$218.8 billion in 2024, comprising:

- bond investment gains of HK$135.9 billion;
- equity investment gains of HK$90.9 billion (of which HK$21.8 billion was from Hong Kong equity investments and HK$69.1 billion from other equity investments);
- a foreign exchange valuation loss of HK$35.6 billion on non-Hong Kong dollar assets; and
- other investment gains of HK$27.6 billion held by the Exchange Fund’s investment holding subsidiaries.

On the other hand, the Strategic Portfolio recorded a valuation gain of HK$2.8 billion.

At the end of 2024, the total assets of the Exchange Fund amounted to HK$40,810 billion. The total market value of the Long-term Growth Portfolio’s investments was HK$5,412 billion, of which private equity accounted for HK$4,348 billion and real estate for HK$1,064 billion. The total amount committed but not yet drawn down for investment in the Long-term Growth Portfolio was HK$2,886 billion.

The Exchange Fund (excluding the Strategic Portfolio) achieved an investment return of 5.2% in 2024, with the Investment Portfolio returning 7.2% and the Backing Portfolio 4.1%. The annualised internal rate of return of the Long-term Growth Portfolio since the commencement of investment in 2009 was 11.2%.
