# 機構職能

機構職能部門支持金管局的運作，保持高透明度與問責性，並發揮卓越的效率及專業水準。為促進公眾對金管局的政策及工作的了解，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體、金管局網站、金管局資訊中心及其他渠道積極與整體社會及市場參與者保持聯繫。

# 傳媒關係及社交媒體應用

金管局與傳媒保持緊密聯繫，以提高透明度及增進公眾對其政策及運作的了解。金管局在2024年共舉辦或參與207次活動，包括14次新聞發布會、四次傳媒簡報會、14次即場訪問及175次其他公開活動。為增進社會對金管局主要職能的認識，金管局為本地、內地及境外的媒體舉辦新聞發布會及傳媒簡報會，涵蓋代幣化、防騙措施及支援中小企措施等主題。年內金管局亦安排25次媒體訪談、發布約600份雙語新聞稿，並處理大量傳媒日常查詢。

傳媒代表積極參與金管局在2024年舉辦的活動，尤其是第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，獲得本地、內地及國際媒體逾萬篇新聞報道。

為更有效聯繫公眾，金管局共營運六個社交媒體專頁（包括Facebook、Instagram、LinkedIn、WeChat、X（前稱Twitter）及YouTube），獲超過200,000名用戶關注。金管局製作富創意的社交媒體內容，提高公眾對一系列議題及舉措的認識，例如防騙、金融科技、綠色和可持續金融、支援中小企及金管局舉辦的大型盛事等。金管局亦在其社交媒體專頁直播「國際金融領袖投資峰會」，促進公眾及業界參與。

# 公眾查詢

金管局的公眾查詢服務為市民提供有效渠道，以增進其對金管局主要職能及運作的認識。

在2024年公眾查詢服務共處理9,594宗查詢（圖1），全部都在金管局服務承諾時限內回覆（表1）。這些查詢中約有一半涉及銀行消費者事宜、金融基建與債券市場發展、銀行業政策及規例，以及紙幣與硬幣（圖2）。常見的查詢包括硬幣收集計劃、銀行產品及服務、零售債券發行計劃、銀行業相關指引與通告，以及「轉數快」。

# 刊物

年內金管局出版《二零二三年年報》及《二零二三年可持續發展報告》。《二零二三年可持續發展報告》在香港會計師公會「最佳企業管治及ESG大獎2024」的「公眾/非牟利機構（大型）」類別中獲得評判嘉許獎。此外，《二零二三年年報》在香港管理專業協會2024年度最佳年報評選中獲得「非牟利及慈善機構」類銅獎。

在2024年，金管局定期更新《金融數據月報》1資料，並出版：

- 兩期《貨幣與金融穩定情況半年度報告》
- 四期《季報》；及
- 14篇《匯思》文章。

# 機構網站

機構網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)提供73,000多頁英文版及繁簡字體中文版資料，方便公眾查閱金管局的最新資訊。網站亦載有根據《銀行業條例》第20條備存的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，以及根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》備存的「儲值支付工具持牌人紀錄冊」。

金管局自2018年起透過開放應用程式介面（開放API），分階段發放在其網站所載的金融數據及重要資訊。截至2024年底，我們按照原定計劃在網站推出合共177組開放API。有關金管局開放API的更詳盡資料，請瀏覽金管局開放API門戶網站(https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk)。

# 資訊中心

金管局資訊中心設於國際金融中心2期55樓，分為展覽館及圖書館兩部分，旨在向公眾介紹金管局的工作，並提高公眾對貨幣與銀行業事宜的認識。展覽館以互動方式簡介金管局的工作，以及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展；另備資料與展品，供研究香港貨幣、銀行業與金融事務。

年內資訊中心接待超過68,000名訪客，較2023年增加約120%。資訊中心亦為學校及其他團體提供570多次導賞服務。

毗鄰展覽館的圖書館收藏超過26,000冊書籍、期刊及其他刊物，涵蓋香港貨幣、銀行業、金融和中央銀行事務等課題。圖書館亦備存《銀行業條例》第20條規定的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，供公眾查閱。

# 社區聯繫及公眾教育

為增進市民對金管局工作的認識，金管局自1998年起推出公眾教育講座，至今錄得參加者人數超過68,000名。於2024年，我們舉行網上講座，吸引800多名來自41間中學的師生參加。講座內容涵蓋金管局工作簡介、聯繫匯率制度、香港鈔票、防騙、存款保障計劃、綠色金融及銀行業發展機遇。

我們使用不同渠道聯繫及教育公眾，提醒他們如何做個精明及負責任的金融服務消費者。2024年的活動合共吸引超過67,000名市民參與。

為配合數碼支付及綠色生活的趨勢，我們透過社交媒體及電台宣傳，鼓勵市民於農曆新年期間派發電子利是，亦可考慮以「迎新鈔」派發實體利是。

# 防騙歌曲 — 《Link咪亂撳》

為進一步加強防騙工作，我們推出由歌手尹光先生與金管局副總裁阮國恒先生合唱的防騙歌曲，提醒市民「假Link咪當真，唔好俾人昆」，以及要妥善保管敏感的個人資料與信用卡資料。跨媒體宣傳活動的成效得到肯定，取得國際推廣殊榮。

# 《跨境理財新機遇》電視短片系列

金管局與一間本地電視台聯合製作《跨境理財新機遇》電視短片系列，協助市民進一步了解「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）為零售投資者在跨境投資上帶來的機遇及便利。這短片系列藉五部膾炙人口的港產電影的「經典場面」，解說「跨境理財通」的框架、投資者的資格要求、「北向通」與「南向通」提供的產品、風險管理，以及跨境投資應注意的事項，並透過電視、數碼及社交媒體平台進行推廣。

# 全港理財爭霸戰

為提高中學生的理財知識，金管局與多個相關機構合作舉辦「全港理財爭霸戰」。該活動在2024年踏入十周年，主題為「未來金融人才」，旨在讓中學生及早認識創新、金融科技、人工智能等發展及未來動向，以及推動學生秉持可持續發展與環境、社會及管治原則。

爭霸戰第一部分是網上問答比賽，測試參賽學生的理財知識及對熱門金融課題的認識。於2024年，來自290所中學共32,000人次參與網上問答比賽，創下歷年新高。在2015年至2024年間，來自440所中學的學生參與爭霸戰的網上問答比賽環節共約125,000次。爭霸戰的第二部分「少年金融人才計劃」以師友形式進行，由不同範疇的資深從業員擔任導師，培訓學生準備參與「設計思維挑戰賽」。在2024年，這部分的爭霸戰更特別增設「大灣區邀請賽」，以促進粵港澳三地學生互動交流。

副總裁陳維民先生在爭霸戰總決賽致歡迎辭，並為總決賽參賽者打氣

參與「少年金融人才計劃」的學生與導師會面

# 桌上教育遊戲

金管局在2023年推出其首個理財教育桌上遊戲《$mart理財321》，並於2024年繼續推廣，讓更多人認識這副原創桌遊，並加強其作為教育工具的用途，讓小學生在模擬情景下認識不同的支付方法、基本理財概念、金融科技及網絡安全。

在社區層面，我們於「香港書展2024」設置攤位，並在聖誕節及農曆新年期間於社區舉辧工作坊，以及在金管局辦事處舉辦親子工作坊，進一步推廣金融及理財概念。此外，我們亦安排到校活動讓小學生試玩，並舉辦培訓工作坊，鼓勵中學教師在新設初中科目「公民、經濟與社會」的理財教育單元中使用桌遊作為教材之一。桌遊得到教育局肯定為出色的教學工具之一，並用作其舉辦的「理財教育學校獎勵計劃」（2023/24）優勝學校的獎品。金管局在2024年合共舉辧約40場桌遊工作坊，獲得超過3,600名學生、家長、教師及社工參與。

在開發《$mart理財321》桌遊的經驗基礎上，金管局推出策略桌遊《企業綠化大變身》，於「香港書展2024」的攤位作為紀念品送出。這是全港首副向學生傳遞綠色金融知識的桌遊。

此外，我們繼續支持投資者及理財教育委員會的工作，提升香港市民的金融知識及理財能力，並會研究與不同持份者進一步合作，提高社區參與工作的成效。

為維持高透明度，金管局採納適用於中央銀行運作的國際財務披露標準，包括香港財務報告準則及國際貨幣基金組織的數據公布特殊標準。財務處在獨立審計師及其他會計專業人員協助下，按照香港財務報告準則編製外匯基金財務報表。此外，金管局在《年報》詳細披露及深入分析預算及支出資料（請參閱第193至194頁「預算編製及財務管控」一節）。

# Institutional Functions

The Institutional Functions Department supports the operations of the HKMA, maintains high levels of transparency and accountability, and delivers excellent efficiency and professionalism. To enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s policies and work, the HKMA actively engages with the wider community and market participants through traditional and social media, the HKMA website, the HKMA Information Centre, and other channels.

Internally, the HKMA is committed to building a flexible and professional workforce, while adhering to strict fiscal discipline and enhancing digital capabilities to respond to changes and ensure effective implementation of policies and measures.

# Maintaining Transparency

# Media Relations and Social Media Applications

The HKMA maintains close contact with the media to enhance transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2024, the HKMA organised or participated in 207 events, including 14 press conferences, four media briefings, 14 on-site interviews, and 175 other public events. To enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s key functions, it organised press conferences and media briefings for local, mainland, and overseas media, covering topics such as tokenisation, anti-fraud measures, and support for SMEs. During the year, the HKMA also arranged 25 media interviews, issued approximately 600 bilingual press releases, and handled a large number of daily media inquiries.

Chief Executive Mr Eddie Yue gave an on-site interview to the media at Hong Kong FinTech Week 2024.

Deputy Chief Executive Mr Darryl Chan delivered a welcome speech at the Use Case Showcase Day for “Account Linkage.”

Media representatives actively participated in events organised by the HKMA in 2024, particularly the third International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit. The three-day summit received over 10,000 news reports from local, mainland, and international media.

Chief Executive Mr Eddie Yue gave a live media interview at the International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit 2024.

Deputy Chief Executive Mr Edmond Lau hosted a media briefing on the establishment of the “SME Financing Taskforce.”

Deputy Chief Executive Mr Brian Chan delivered an opening speech at the 2024 Treasury Markets Summit.

To communicate more effectively with the public, the HKMA operates six social media pages (Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, WeChat, X (formerly Twitter), and YouTube), with over 200,000 followers. The HKMA creates creative social media content to raise public awareness of issues and initiatives such as anti-fraud, fintech, green and sustainable finance, support for SMEs, and major HKMA events. The HKMA also live-streamed the International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit on its social media pages to promote public and industry participation.

Publishing creative content on social media helps increase public awareness of the HKMA’s initiatives and various issues.

# Public Enquiries

The HKMA’s public enquiry service provides an effective channel for citizens to enhance their understanding of the HKMA’s key functions and operations.

In 2024, the public enquiry service handled 9,594 enquiries (Chart 1), all of which were responded to within the HKMA’s service commitment timeframe (Table 1). About half of these enquiries related to banking consumer matters, financial infrastructure and bond market development, banking policies and regulations, and banknotes and coins (Chart 2). Common enquiries included coin collection programmes, banking products and services, retail bond issuance programmes, banking-related guidelines and notices, and the Faster Payment System.

# Publications

During the year, the HKMA published the *2023 Annual Report* and the *2023 Sustainability Report*. The *2023 Sustainability Report* received a Judges’ Commendation Award in the “Public/Non-profit Organisation (Large)” category at the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants’ Best Corporate Governance and ESG Awards 2024. The *2023 Annual Report* won a bronze award in the “Non-profit and Charitable Organisations” category at the Hong Kong Management Association’s 2024 Best Annual Report Awards.

In 2024, the HKMA regularly updated the *Financial Data Monthly Bulletin* and published:

- Two issues of the *Semi-annual Report on Monetary and Financial Stability*;
- Four issues of the *Quarterly Bulletin*; and
- 14 *Exchange Thoughts* articles.

# Corporate Website

The corporate website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 73,000 pages of information in English and traditional and simplified Chinese, making it easy for the public to access the latest information about the HKMA. The website also contains the “Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices” and the “Register of Securities Employees of Authorised Institutions” maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the “Register of Licensees of Stored Value Payment Instruments” maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Payment Instruments Ordinance.

Since 2018, the HKMA has been releasing financial data and key information on its website in phases through open application programming interfaces (open APIs). As of the end of 2024, it had launched a total of 177 open APIs on the website as planned. For more details on the HKMA’s open APIs, please visit the HKMA Open API Portal (https://apidocs.hkma.gov.hk).

# Information Centre

The HKMA Information Centre, located on the 55th floor of Two International Finance Centre, consists of an exhibition gallery and a library. Its purpose is to introduce the HKMA’s work to the public and enhance public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The exhibition gallery introduces the HKMA’s work and the development of Hong Kong’s currency and banking system in an interactive manner, and provides materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, and financial affairs.

During the year, the Information Centre received over 68,000 visitors, an increase of about 120% compared to 2023. The Information Centre also provided over 570 guided tours for schools and other groups.

Adjacent to the exhibition gallery, the library houses over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, finance, and central banking. The library also maintains the “Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices” and the “Register of Securities Employees of Authorised Institutions” under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance for public inspection.

Kindergarten students participated in a guided tour at the Information Centre to learn about Hong Kong banknotes.

Information Centre staff introduced a mosaic of Hong Kong’s harbour made from local coins to visitors.

# Community Engagement and Public Education

To enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s work, the HKMA has been organising public education seminars since 1998, with over 68,000 participants to date. In 2024, it held online seminars that attracted over 800 teachers and students from 41 secondary schools. The seminars covered topics such as an introduction to the HKMA’s work, the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong banknotes, anti-fraud measures, the deposit protection scheme, green finance, and banking development opportunities.

The HKMA uses various channels to engage and educate the public on how to be smart and responsible financial services consumers. In 2024, its activities attracted over 67,000 participants.

In line with the trend of digital payments and green living, the HKMA used social media and radio to encourage people to send electronic red packets during the Lunar New Year, or to consider sending physical red packets with new banknotes.

An animated video was produced to encourage the sending of electronic red packets.

# Anti-fraud song – *Link咪亂撳*

To further strengthen anti-fraud efforts, the HKMA released an anti-fraud song performed by singer Mr Wan Kwong and HKMA Deputy Chief Executive Mr Edmond Lau, reminding the public “Don’t trust fake links, don’t let people scam you,” and to safeguard sensitive personal and credit card information. The cross-media campaign was successful and received international recognition.

Deputy Chief Executive Mr Edmond Lau (right) participated in the performance of the anti-fraud song.

The cross-media campaign raised public awareness of anti-fraud measures.

# *New Opportunities for Cross-border Wealth Management* TV series

The HKMA co-produced a TV series, *New Opportunities for Cross-border Wealth Management*, with a local television station to help the public better understand the opportunities and convenience that the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect (“Wealth Management Connect”) brings to retail investors in cross-border investment. The series used “classic scenes” from five popular Hong Kong movies to explain the framework of Wealth Management Connect, investor eligibility requirements, the products offered by Northbound and Southbound Connect, risk management, and matters to note for cross-border investment. It was promoted through television, digital, and social media platforms.

The series introduced Wealth Management Connect in a humorous way.

# Territory-wide Financial Literacy Championship

To enhance financial literacy among secondary school students, the HKMA collaborated with various organisations to organise the Territory-wide Financial Literacy Championship. In 2024, the event celebrated its 10th anniversary with the theme “Future Financial Talent,” aiming to help secondary school students understand early on the developments and future trends in innovation, fintech, artificial intelligence, and sustainable development, as well as environmental, social, and governance principles.

The first part of the competition was an online quiz testing participants’ financial knowledge and understanding of popular financial topics. In 2024, a record-breaking 32,000 students from 290 secondary schools participated in the online quiz. Between 2015 and 2024, students from 440 secondary schools participated in the online quiz segment of the competition approximately 125,000 times. The second part of the competition, the “Junior Financial Talent Programme,” was conducted in a mentorship format, with experienced professionals from various fields serving as mentors to train students for the “Design Thinking Challenge.” In 2024, this part of the competition also featured a “Greater Bay Area Invitational” to promote interaction and exchange among students from Hong Kong, Guangdong, and Macao.

Deputy Chief Executive Mr Brian Chan delivered a welcome speech at the final of the competition and cheered on the finalists.

Students participating in the Junior Financial Talent Programme met with their mentors.

# Educational board game

In 2023, the HKMA launched its first financial education board game, *$mart Finance 321*, and continued to promote it in 2024 to raise awareness of this original game and enhance its use as an educational tool. The game allows primary school students to learn about different payment methods, basic financial concepts, fintech, and cyber security in a simulated environment.

At the community level, the HKMA set up a booth at the Hong Kong Book Fair 2024 and organised workshops in the community during Christmas and the Lunar New Year, as well as parent-child workshops at the HKMA office, to further promote financial and money management concepts. It also organised school visits for primary school students to try out the game and training workshops to encourage secondary school teachers to use the game as teaching material in the new junior secondary subject “Civics, Economics and Society” for financial education. The game was recognised by the Education Bureau as an excellent teaching tool and was used as a prize for winning schools in its Financial Education School Awards Programme (2023/24). In 2024, the HKMA organised approximately 40 board game workshops, attracting over 3,600 students, parents, teachers, and social workers.

Based on the experience of developing the *$mart Finance 321* board game, the HKMA launched a strategy board game, *Corporate Green Transformation*, which was given away as a souvenir at the Hong Kong Book Fair 2024 booth. This is the first board game in Hong Kong to teach students about green finance.

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：

- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；

- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及

-計劃並執行集團審計，以就集團中實體或業務單位的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，作為對財務報表形成意見的基礎。我負責指導、監督和審視為進行集團審計而履行的審計工作。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

# Report of the Director of Audit

# Audit Commission of the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

# Independent Auditor’s Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries (the “Group”) set out on pages 209 to 309, which comprise the Group’s balance sheet as at 31 December 2024, and the related income statement, comprehensive income statement, statement of changes in equity and cash flow statement for the year then ended, together with the notes to the financial statements, including a summary of significant accounting policies.

In my opinion, the financial statements present a true and fair view of the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2024, and of their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants. They have also been properly prepared in compliance with the directions given by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66).

# Basis for opinion

I conducted my audit in accordance with the directions given by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the auditing standards of the Audit Commission. My responsibilities under those standards are further described in the “Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements” section of my report. I am independent of the Group in accordance with these standards and have fulfilled my other ethical responsibilities under them. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my audit opinion.

# Key audit matters

Key audit matters are those matters that, in my professional judgment, were of most significance in my audit of the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2024. These matters were addressed in the context of my audit of the financial statements as a whole, and in forming my opinion thereon, and I do not provide a separate opinion on these matters.

# Valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value

Refer to notes 2.5, 2.6 and 37.1 to the financial statements.

As at 31 December 2024, the Group’s financial assets measured at fair value totalled HK$39,151.17 billion, and its financial liabilities totalled HK$13,862.99 billion.

For 86% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities, fair values were based on quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets (Level 1 inputs), or were estimated using valuation techniques where the inputs were based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The remaining 14% of these financial assets had fair values estimated using valuation techniques where the inputs were not based on observable market data (Level 3 inputs). These financial assets totalled HK$5,522.51 billion and primarily comprised unlisted investment funds.

Given the significant amounts involved and the estimation required, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value was a key audit matter.

My audit procedures in relation to the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value included the following:

- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and financial liabilities, including related monitoring controls;

- Evaluating and testing monitoring controls, including relevant application controls in computer systems;

- Obtaining confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and financial liabilities;

- Verifying prices against independent sources when market quotations were used;

- When valuation techniques used inputs based on observable market data, evaluating whether the valuation techniques were appropriate and the assumptions were reasonable, and verifying the inputs against independent sources; and

- When valuation techniques used inputs not based on observable market data, evaluating whether the valuation techniques were appropriate and whether the assumptions and inputs were reasonable.

# Valuation of investment properties measured at fair value

Refer to notes 2.11, 17 and 18 to the financial statements.

The Group’s investment properties were measured at fair value and totalled HK$21.132 billion as at 31 December 2024. The Group also held interests in associates and joint ventures whose principal activities were holding overseas investment properties. Regardless of whether they were held directly by the Group or by associates or joint ventures, the fair values of these investment properties were primarily determined based on valuations by independent professional valuers. These valuations involved significant judgment and estimation, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

My audit procedures in relation to the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value included the following:

- Obtaining and reviewing valuation reports for investment properties held directly by the Group or by associates or joint ventures, and verifying that the fair values were determined based on the valuations set out in those reports;

- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and

- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate and whether the assumptions and inputs were reasonable.

# Other information

The Financial Management Commissioner is responsible for the other information. The other information comprises all the information in the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s 2024 Annual Report, but does not include the financial statements and my auditor’s report thereon.

My opinion on the financial statements does not cover the other information, and I do not express any form of assurance conclusion thereon.

In connection with my audit of the financial statements, I am responsible for reading the other information and considering whether it is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or my knowledge obtained during the audit, or otherwise appears to be materially misstated. If, based on the work I have performed, I conclude that there is a material misstatement of this other information, I am required to report that fact. I have nothing to report in this regard.

# Responsibilities of the Financial Management Commissioner and the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee in relation to the financial statements

The Financial Management Commissioner is responsible for preparing financial statements that present a true and fair view in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the directions given by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and for implementing such internal control as is considered necessary to enable the preparation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

In preparing the financial statements, the Financial Management Commissioner is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting.

The Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group’s financial reporting process.

# Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the auditing standards of the Audit Commission will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements.

As part of an audit conducted in accordance with the auditing standards of the Audit Commission, I exercise professional judgment and maintain professional scepticism throughout the audit. I also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.

- Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal control.

- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used by the Financial Management Commissioner and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the Financial Management Commissioner.

- Conclude on the appropriateness of the Financial Management Commissioner’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that a material uncertainty exists, I am required to draw attention in my auditor’s report to the related disclosures in the financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify my opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of my auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to continue as a going concern.

- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the financial statements, including the disclosures, and whether the financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation.

- Plan and perform an audit of the Group in order to obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence about the financial information of the entities or business units within the Group to provide a basis for my opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising and reviewing the work performed to conduct the audit of the Group. I am solely responsible for my audit opinion.

I communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control that I identify during my audit.

I also provide a statement to the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee that I have complied with relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicate with them all relationships and other matters that may reasonably be thought to bear on my independence, and the related safeguards, if applicable.

From the matters communicated with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, I determine those matters that were of most significance in the audit of the financial statements for the current period and are therefore the key audit matters. I describe these matters in my auditor’s report unless law or regulation precludes public disclosure about the matter or, in extremely rare circumstances, I determine that a matter should not be communicated in my report because the adverse consequences of doing so would reasonably be expected to outweigh the public interest benefits of such communication.

# Exchange Fund – Notes to the Financial Statements

(All amounts are expressed in millions of Hong Kong dollars, unless otherwise stated.)

# 1 Principal activities

The Financial Management Commissioner manages the Exchange Fund (the Fund) in accordance with the authority granted by the Financial Secretary as its manager and the provisions of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66). The Fund’s principal activities are to defend the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate and to maintain the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system.

The Fund’s assets are managed across four distinct portfolios: the Backing Portfolio, the Investment Portfolio, the Long-term Growth Portfolio, and the Strategic Assets Portfolio. Under Hong Kong’s Currency Board System, the assets in the Backing Portfolio fully match the monetary base. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in bond and equity markets of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development member countries.
